elements.content: Three silver(I) coordination polymers, namely, [Ag2(PyBIm)2(H2O)2]SO4·H2O (1), [Ag3(PyBIm)3(μ2-SO4)(HSO4)]·3H2O (2), and [Ag2(PyBIm)2(μ2-SO4)]·4H2O (3) [PyBIm = 2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole] have been synthesized by hydrothermal methods. The Ag(I) atoms in 1−3 are all three coordinated, bridged by PyBIm ligands via NPy and NBIm donor atoms into a one-dimensional “zigzag” chain based on the [Ag2(PyBIm)2]2+ unit. The sulfate groups are not coordinated in 1, while they act as bridging ligands in 2 and 3; with the help of μ2-SO4, such “zigzag” chains are linked into a belt with a ternary-chain structural motif in 2; however, in 3, a two-dimensional network is observed. All the complexes display room-temperature photoluminescence in the visible region, which may be assigned to metal-to-ligand charge transfer.

The sulfate groups are not coordinated in 1, while they act as bridging ligands in 2 and 3; with the help of μ2-SO4, such "zigzag" chains are linked into a belt with a ternary-chain structural motif in 2; however, in 3, a two-dimensional network is observed. All the complexes display room-temperature photoluminescence in the visible region, which may be assigned to metal-to-ligand charge transfer.

elements.content: Three silver(I) coordination polymers were prepared under hydrothermal reactions with PyBIm and Ag2SO4 in different conditions. The results show that the concentration of SO4 2- and pH values of the solutions play important roles in the formation of these three compounds.

elements.content: Pronounced interest has recently been focused on the crystal engineering of supramolecular architectures organized by coordinate covalent bonds or supramolecular contacts such as hydrogen bonding and π−π interactions. However, the influencing information on coordination polymers are not yet well understood, although the self-assembly of these architectures has been documented to be heavily influenced by various factors such as the functionality and denticity of ligands, the molar ratio of the reagents, the pH value of the solution, and steric requirements of the counterions. The exploration of synthetic strategies and routines is therefore a long-term challenge, and a great deal of work is required to extend the knowledge of relevant structural types and establish proper synthetic strategies leading to desirable supramolecular species.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Pronounced interest has recently been focused on the crystal engineering of supramolecular architectures organized by coordinate covalent bonds or supramolecular contacts such as hydrogen bonding and π-π interactions. However, the influencing information on coordination polymers are not yet well understood, although the self-assembly of these architectures has been documented to be heavily influenced by various factors such as the functionality and denticity of ligands, the molar ratio of the reagents, the pH value of the solution, and steric requirements of the counterions. The exploration of synthetic strategies and routines is therefore a long-term challenge, and a great deal of work is required to extend the knowledge of relevant structural types and establish proper synthetic strategies leading to desirable supramolecular species.

elements.content: Recently, a series of silver(I) complexes with a similar formula [Ag(4,4‘-bipyridine)]X (X = NO3 -, BF4 -, NO2 -, CH3CO2 -, H2PO4 -, CF3SO3 - ) have been reported, and interesting structural versatility has been demonstrated. These silver(I) atoms exhibit linear, T-shaped, even tetrahedral coordination. The crystal structure may be described as a one-dimensional (1D) chain, molar ladder, or three-dimensional framework. However, studies on silver(I) complexes with asymmetric bipyridine are rather insufficient, and only three silver(I) complexes with 2,4‘-bipyridine have been reported. These three silver(I) complexes that have been reported are [Ag2(2,4‘-bpy)2(SO4)(H2O)]·5H2O, [Ag(2,4‘-bpy)](ClO4), and [Ag(2,4‘-bpy)](NO3). [Ag2(2,4‘-bpy)2(SO4)(H2O)]·5H2O was reported to have a 1D chain based on (Ag−bpy−Ag) units, while such 1D chains were linked through long Ag···Ag interactions into a 2D sheet in [Ag(2,4‘-bpy)](ClO4); in [Ag(2,4‘-bpy)](NO3), the chains were bridged into a 2D network by NO3 - groups rather than Ag···Ag interactions.

These silver(I) atoms exhibit linear, T-shaped, even tetrahedral coordination. The crystal structure may be described as a one-dimensional (1D) chain, molar ladder, or three-dimensional framework. However, studies on silver(I) complexes with asymmetric bipyridine are rather insufficient, and only three silver(I) complexes with 2,4‘-bipyridine have been reported. These three silver(I) complexes that have been reported are [Ag2(2,4‘-bpy)2(SO4)(H2O)]⋅5H2O, [Ag(2,4‘-bpy)](ClO4), and [Ag(2,4‘-bpy)](NO3). [Ag2(2,4‘-bpy)2(SO4)(H2O)]⋅5H2O was reported to have a 1D chain based on (Ag-bpy-Ag) units, while such 1D chains were linked through long Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions into a 2D sheet in [Ag(2,4‘-bpy)](ClO4); in [Ag(2,4‘-bpy)](NO3), the chains were bridged into a 2D network by NO3 - groups rather than Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions.

elements.content: To investigate supramolecular reactions and conversion, three silver(I) coordination polymers, namely, [Ag2(PyBIm)2(H2O)2]SO4·H2O (1), [Ag3(PyBIm)3(μ2-SO4)(HSO4)]·3H2O (2), and [Ag2(PyBIm)2(μ2-SO4)]·4H2O (3), were synthesized by the reaction of an asymmetric ligand 2-(4-pyridyl)benzimidazole with Ag2SO4 under different molar ratios and pH values of the solution. Among them, two crystallize in the chiral space group, and the third crystallizes in the triclinic P1̄ space group. The bidentate ligands PyBIm bridge the silver(I) atoms into a “zigzag” chain based on [Ag2(PyBIm)2]2+ units in complexes 1−3. The sulfate groups are not coordinated to silver(I) atoms in 1 but act as bridging ligands in 2 and 3. Interestingly, complex 2 features a 1D belt with a ternary chain, while 3 is attributed to a two-dimensional (2D) network. The N−H groups of benzimidazoyl form strong hydrogen bonds with lattice water or sulfate groups, which contribute to the packing of complexes.

Interestingly, complex 2 features a 1D belt with a ternary chain, while 3 is attributed to a two-dimensional (2D) network. The N-H groups of benzimidazoyl form strong hydrogen bonds with lattice water or sulfate groups, which contribute to the packing of complexes.

elements.content: Materials. The ligand (PyBIm) was synthesized in accordance with the procedure reported by Alcade et al. Other reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were carried out on a Elementar Vario EL III analyzer, and the IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT IR spectrometer in the range of 400−4000 cm-1. Fluorescence measurements were made on an Edinburgh Analytical instrument FLS920. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed with a NETSCHZ STA-499C thermoanalyzer under N2 (30−800 °C range) at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray powder diffractions (XRPD) were performed on Bruker D8 Advanced diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials. The ligand (PyBIm) was synthesized in accordance with the procedure reported by Alcade et al. Other reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were carried out on a Elementar Vario EL III analyzer, and the IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT IR spectrometer in the range of 400-4000 cm-1. Fluorescence measurements were made on an Edinburgh Analytical instrument FLS920. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed with a NETSCHZ STA-499C thermoanalyzer under N2 (30-800 °C range) at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. X-ray powder diffractions (XRPD) were performed on Bruker D8 Advanced diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature.

elements.content: Syntheses. (a) [Ag 2 (PyBIm) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ]SO 4 · H 2 O (1). A solution of Ag2SO4 (0.19 g, 0.61 mmol), PyBIm (0.24 g, 1.22 mmol), and H2O (15 mL) was stirred under ambient conditions, then sealed in Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated at 170 °C for 5 days, and cooled to room temperature. The resulting product was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried in air (80% yield). Anal. Calcd for C24H24 Ag2N6O7S:  C, 38.11; H, 3.20; N, 11.11; S, 4.23. Found:  C, 38.00; H, 3.32; N, 11.00; S, 4.33. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  1613.8s, 1441.5m, 1319.5w, 1227.9w, 1053.6s, 757.1m, 605.1w.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Suitable single crystals of 1−3 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were collected on a siemens SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298 K. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 by using the SHELX-97 program package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of PyBIm were generated geometrically, and no attempts were made to locate the hydrogen atoms of water and the hydrosulfate group. The crystallography details for the structures determination of 1−3 are presented in Table . Selected bond distances and bond angles are listed in Table .

Syntheses and Characterization. Attempts to obtain the products by the reaction of PyBIm and Ag2SO4 under solution conditions failed. When the sample was refluxed in acetonitrile−water solution for a day, the white powder turned into crystals of very poor quality. Hydrothermal synthesis provides an efficient method for the preparation and crystallization of organic−inorganic materials of the oxide family, and this strategy was adopted for the reaction of Ag2SO4 with PyBIm in water under varied conditions. When Ag2SO4 and PyBIm in a molar ratio of 1:1 were heated at 120 °C for 5 days, both complexes 1 and 3 could be obtained as an inseparable mixture with 3 in poor quality. When the reaction temperature was increased to 160 °C, complex 1 could be produced as an objective product without 3 as a byproduct (see Supporting Information). Too much Na2SO4 could reduce the solubility of Ag2SO4 greatly and might lead to failure in the preparation of 3. Whether appropriate crystals could be obtained by the diffusion method is still under investigation in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Syntheses and Characterization. Attempts to obtain the products by the reaction of PyBIm and Ag2SO4 under solution conditions failed. When the sample was refluxed in acetonitrile-water solution for a day, the white powder turned into crystals of very poor quality. Hydrothermal synthesis provides an efficient method for the preparation and crystallization of organic-inorganic materials of the oxide family, and this strategy was adopted for the reaction of Ag2SO4 with PyBIm in water under varied conditions. When Ag2SO4 and PyBIm in a molar ratio of 1:1 were heated at 120 °C for 5 days, both complexes 1 and 3 could be obtained as an inseparable mixture with 3 in poor quality. When the reaction temperature was increased to 160 °C, complex 1 could be produced as an objective product without 3 as a byproduct (see Supporting Information). Too much Na2SO4 could reduce the solubility of Ag2SO4 greatly and might lead to failure in the preparation of 3. Whether appropriate crystals could be obtained by the diffusion method is still under investigation in our laboratory.

elements.content: The TGA diagrams show that these three complexes have similar stability and behavior in the range of 100− 500 °C, all displaying loss of water around 80−260 °C. Complex 1 exhibits loss of one lattice water and two coordinated ones in two steps between 80 and 261 °C (7.04% weight loss observed; 7.14% calculated). In contrast, complex 2 exhibits loss of three water molecules between 74 and 203 °C (4.73% weight loss observed; 4.66% calculated). While complex 3 exhibits loss of three of the four water molecules between 89 and 229 °C (9.25% weight loss observed; 9.30% calculated; see Supporting Information). Subsequently, all these three complexes exhibit sharp weight losses between approximately 260−480 °C in two steps, followed by slow weight losses. The common behavior of these three species suggests that a common series of intermediates might exist.

elements.content: Crystal Structures. Compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral space group P65; the absolute structure was determined from the Flack parameter refined to be 0.01(7), indicating the complex is of correct absolute structure. The single-crystal X-ray structure analysis reveals that 1 is a 1D [Ag2(PyBIm)2(H2O)2]∞ “zigzag” chain (Figure ). All the silver(I) atoms are three-coordinated, and each bonds with one aqua ligand [Ag(1)−O(1w) 2.502(11) Å, Ag(2)−O(2w) 2.574(10) Å] and two PyBIm ligands via the NPy and NBIm nitrogen donor atoms [Ag(1)−N(1) 2.217(11) Å, Ag(1)−N(5) 2.165(10) Å, Ag(2)−N(2) 2.189(12) Å, Ag(2)−N(4) 2.210(11) Å] and exhibits distorted “T” shaped coordination [NPy−Ag−NBIm = 152.0(4)° for Ag(1) and 157.8(4)° for Ag(2), NPy−Ag−Ow = 88.2(5)° for Ag(1) and 91.0(4)° for Ag(2), NBIm−Ag−Ow = 119.4(4)° for Ag(1) and 110.8(4)° for Ag(2)] (Figure ). As the benzimidazoyl group is a more electron-rich ligand than is pyridyl, the Ag−N(benzimidazoyl) [2.189(12), 2.165(10) Å, respectively] distances are slightly shorter than those of Ag−N(pyridiyl) [(2.217(11), 2.210(11) Å, respectively); the same results have been observed by others.

elements.content: The benzimidazoyl rings are almost coplanar in the “zigzag” chain, and the pyridyl ring deviates from the benzimidazoyl ring of the same PyBIm ligand with a dihedral angle of 27.2° and 35.1°, respectively. The silver(I) atoms are bridged by PyBIm ligands with a separation of approximately 7.208 to 7.306 Å. The N−H groups of benzimidazoyl form strong hydrogen bonds with oxygen atoms of the sulfate group and lattice water (Figure ) [N(6)−H(6a)···O(3) 2.660(19) Å, N(3)−H(3a)···O(3w) 2.702(15) Å] (Table ). Generally, in the Ag−SO4 coordination system, the sulfate groups always coordinate to the metal ion. Only two exceptions were observed in which the anion only acts as counterion. Complex 1 adds a new example and will certainly provide interesting and useful information for the systemic study in this field.

Compound 2 crystallizes as racemic twin in the space group P212121 with the Flack parameter refined to be 0.48(3). Its structure may be described as a belt formed by a ternary chain (Figure ). In the complex, there are three crystallographically independent Ag(I) atoms with two types of coordination geometries. Besides being coordinated by two PyBIm ligands via NPy and NBIm donor atoms [Ag(1)−N(7) 2.201(4) Å, Ag(1)−N(3) 2.183(4) Å, Ag(2)−N(1) 2.204(4) Å, Ag(2)−N(8) 2.175(4) Å, Ag(3)−N(4) 2.193(4) Å, Ag(3)−N(6) 2.160(4) Å], Ag(2) also coordinates to the terminal hydrosulfate group with O(8) [Ag(2)−O(8) 2.398(4) Å], while Ag(1) and Ag(3) also coordinate to the bridging sulfate group with O(3) and O(4) [Ag−O 2.591(3), 2.479(3) Å respectively]. All the silver atoms show a distorted “T” shaped coordination, and the NPy−Ag−NBim angles vary from 155.00(15) to 157.78(15)° [N(3)−Ag(1)−N(7) = 155.00(15)°, N(1)−Ag(2)−N(8) = 156.78(15)°, N(4)−Ag(3)−N(6) = 157.26(14)°], NPy−Ag−O vary from 92.15(13)° to 94.93(15)° [N(7)−Ag(1)−O(4) = 94.32(13)°, N(1)−Ag(2)−O(8) = 94.93(15)°, N(4)−Ag(3)−O(3) = 92.15(13)°], NBIm−Ag−O vary from 107.21(15)° to 110.56(12)° [N(3)−Ag(1)−O(4) = 107.28(13)°, N(8)−Ag(2)−O(8) = 107.21(15)°, N(6)−Ag(3)−O(3) = 110.56(12)°] (Figure ).

elements.content: The O(6) of hydrosulfate forms strong hydrogen bonds with O(3) of the adjacent chain in the distance of 2.506 Å. The S(2)−O(6)H [1.552(4) Å] distance is much longer than the other S−O distances [S(2)−O(5) 1.471(4) Å, S(2)−O(7) 1.455(4) Å] of the same hydrosulfate group. The same result has been observed in other work. It is also longer than the distance of S(1)−O(1) and S(1)−O(2) of bridging sulfate. To the best of our knowledge, compound 2 is the first silver(I) complex that contains both a bridging sulfate and a terminal hydrosulfate group.

elements.content: Bidentate PyBIm ligands bridge silver(I) atoms in a “zigzag” chain similar to that of complex 1. The silver(I) atoms are bridged by the PyBIm with a separation of 7.572 or 7.554 Å in the interchain, which were further connected by bridging sulfate groups into a belt with a ternary chain. The pyridyl ring deviates from the benzimidazoyl ring of the same PyBIm ligand with a dihedral angle of 19.0°, 19.1°, and 20.9°, respectively. The benzimidazoyl rings are almost coplanar in the same chain; however, they have a dihedral angle of 9.0° to 11.2° deviation between the adjacent chains.

The pyridyl ring deviates from the benzimidazoyl ring of the same PyBIm ligand with a dihedral angle of 19.0°, 19.1°, and 20.9°, respectively. The benzimidazoyl rings are almost coplanar in the same chain; however, they have a dihedral angle of 9.0° to 11.2° deviation between the adjacent chains.

elements.content: The “zigzag” chain stacks face to face with benzimidazoyl groups of distances of 3.2 to 3.6 Å, falling in a separation of π−π interactions, which is also shorter than the nearest Ag−Ag distance (4.218 Å) of a different chain. The sides of the adjacent belt are similarly separated by 3.7 Å, also suggesting weak π−π interactions. The ternary chain is different from the commonly reported molecular ladder and molecular railroad, which only have two chains.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray structure analysis reveals that 3 is attributed to a 2D network (Figure ). All the silver(I) atoms are three-coordinated, besides being bridged by PyBIm ligands via NPy and NBIm donor atoms [Ag(1)−N(4) 2.230(3) Å, Ag(1)−N(2) 2.173(3) Å, Ag(2)−N(1) 2.190(3) Å, Ag(2)−N(5) 2.163(3) Å], and each silver(I) atom bridged by one bridging sulfate via two oxygen atoms [Ag(1)−O(2) 2.393(3) Å, Ag(2)−O(1) 2.560(3) Å] exhibits a distorted “T” shaped coordination [N(2)−Ag(1)−N(4) = 152.27(11)°, N(2)−Ag(1)−O(2) = 114.81(11)°, N(4)−Ag(1)−O(2) = 92.90(11)°, N(1)−Ag(2)−N(5) = 156.05(11)°, N(1)−Ag(2)−O(1) = 93.56(11)°, N(5)−Ag(2)−O(1) = 109.88(10)°] (Figure ).

elements.content: Silver(I) atoms are bridged by bidentate PyBIm ligands into a “zigzag” chain similar to that of complexes 1 and 2 with a separation of 7.354 Å, which are further connected by bridging sulfate groups into a 2D network. The pyridyl ring deviates from the benzimidazoyl ring of the same PyBIm ligand with a dihedral angle of 7.4° and 29.4°, respectively. The benzimidazoyl rings are almost coplanar in the same chain and parallel to each other between different chains with a dihedral angle of only 6.5°. Strong π−π interactions exist both intra- and inter- the 2D sheet with a separation of approximately 3.3 to 3.6 Å.

elements.content: Compared with the “zigzag” chain structures in 1−3 show different structural motifs. The differences in these complexes were generated by the different existence modes and functional roles of the sulfate groups. The high concentration of the sulfate anion plays an important role in affecting the syntheses of 2 and 3. In 1, it acts only as a counterion, while in 2 and 3, it acts as a bridging ligand. Furthermore, the pH value also affects the final product; when the solution was acidified to pH = 3, hydrosulfate groups were produced, which act as terminal ligands in 2 and prevent bridging sulfate groups from connecting the 1D “zigzag” chains into a 2D network.

elements.content: Fluorescent Properties. Complexes 1−3 and free PyBIm ligand exhibit photoluminescence in the solid state at room temperature. The emission spectra are shown in Figure . The weak emission of free PyBIm with energy from 450 to 600 nm (max = 492 nm) upon excitation at 370 nm might be assigned to intraligand charge-transfer (LCT). Excitation of solid samples of 1 and 3 at λ = 440 nm, respectively, produce an intense luminescence with a peak maximum at 540 nm, with the peak of 3 broader than that of 1. Excitation of solid samples of 2 at λ = 450 nm produces an intense luminescence with maximum peak at 583 and 653 nm. Such low energy might come from the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer.

cln_elements.content:
Syntheses. (a) [Ag 2 (PyBIm) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ]SO 4 · H 2 O (1). A solution of Ag2SO4 (0.19 g, 0.61 mmol), PyBIm (0.24 g, 1.22 mmol), and H2O (15 mL) was stirred under ambient conditions, then sealed in Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated at 170 °C for 5 days, and cooled to room temperature. The resulting product was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried in air (80% yield). Anal. Calcd for C24H24 Ag2N6O7S:  C, 38.11; H, 3.20; N, 11.11; S, 4.23. Found:  C, 38.00; H, 3.32; N, 11.00; S, 4.33. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  1613.8s, 1441.5m, 1319.5w, 1227.9w, 1053.6s, 757.1m, 605.1w.

(b) [Ag 3 (PyBIm) 3 ( μ 2 -SO 4 )HSO 4 ] · 3H 2 O (2). The procedure was similar to that for 1 except that the mixed solution was acidified with 1 mol L-1 H2SO4 to pH = 3 (78% yield). Anal. Calcd for C36H34Ag3N9O7S2:  C, 37.39; H, 2.96; N, 10.90; S, 5.53. Found:  C, 37.00; H, 3.05; N, 10.42; S, 5.33. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  1614.7s, 1497.4w, 1443.5s, 1319.9m, 1231.0m, 1135.5s, 756.2m, 567.1w.

(c) [Ag 2 (PyBIm) 2 ( μ 2 -SO 4 )] · 4H 2 O (3). The procedure was similar to 1, except that Na2SO4 (0.20 g, 1.41 mmol) was added to the solution of Ag2SO4 (0.19 g, 0.61 mmol), PyBIm (0.24 g, 1.21 mmol), and 15 mL of H2O (80% yield). Anal. Calcd for C24H26Ag2N6O8S:  C, 37.22; H, 3.38; N, 10.86; S, 4.13. Found:  C, 37.00; H, 3.92; N, 10.48; S, 4.03. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  1614.2s, 1496.6w, 1442.9s, 1319.5m, 1227.5m, 1056.9s, 758.0m, 604.2w.

cln_elements.content:
The TGA diagrams show that these three complexes have similar stability and behavior in the range of 100− 500 °C, all displaying loss of water around 80−260 °C. Complex 1 exhibits loss of one lattice water and two coordinated ones in two steps between 80 and 261 °C (7.04% weight loss observed; 7.14% calculated). In contrast, complex 2 exhibits loss of three water molecules between 74 and 203 °C (4.73% weight loss observed; 4.66% calculated). While complex 3 exhibits loss of three of the four water molecules between 89 and 229 °C (9.25% weight loss observed; 9.30% calculated; see Supporting Information). Subsequently, all these three complexes exhibit sharp weight losses between approximately 260−480 °C in two steps, followed by slow weight losses. The common behavior of these three species suggests that a common series of intermediates might exist.

Fluorescent Properties. Complexes 1−3 and free PyBIm ligand exhibit photoluminescence in the solid state at room temperature. The emission spectra are shown in Figure . The weak emission of free PyBIm with energy from 450 to 600 nm (max = 492 nm) upon excitation at 370 nm might be assigned to intraligand charge-transfer (LCT). Excitation of solid samples of 1 and 3 at λ = 440 nm, respectively, produce an intense luminescence with a peak maximum at 540 nm, with the peak of 3 broader than that of 1. Excitation of solid samples of 2 at λ = 450 nm produces an intense luminescence with maximum peak at 583 and 653 nm. Such low energy might come from the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer.

The common behavior of these three species suggests that a common series of intermediates might exist. 

 Fluorescent Properties. Complexes 1-3 and free PyBIm ligand exhibit photoluminescence in the solid state at room temperature. The emission spectra are shown in Figure . The weak emission of free PyBIm with energy from 450 to 600 nm (max = 492 nm) upon excitation at 370 nm might be assigned to intraligand charge-transfer (LCT). Excitation of solid samples of 1 and 3 at λ = 440 nm, respectively, produce an intense luminescence with a peak maximum at 540 nm, with the peak of 3 broader than that of 1. Excitation of solid samples of 2 at λ = 450 nm produces an intense luminescence with maximum peak at 583 and 653 nm. Such low energy might come from the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer.
